attributes.comment:
Based on GAO reports and my experience with both the L1 and H-1b visa, increased
fees are needed so that the government may address shortfalls in enforcement of
both labor and immigration laws.

However, I believe these fees should be the responsibility of sponsoring
companies and not the individual. It is unreasonable to believe that companies
won't pass the cost on to the worker, so stronger laws are certainly needed.

As your job is not to draft laws but simply enforce them, I also believe the
USCIS and DOL is negligent in enforcing the few protections that do exist. For
example,
prevailing wages aren't being met and there are multiple sources used to
determine the wage. This creates a program used to deliver cheap and exploited
labor, not skilled labor. Studies have shown that H-1b workers are in fact paid
below
prevailing wages and nothing is being done to stop this practice. This program
makes occupations, such as software engineering, less attractive to the American
workforce and has resulted in fewer admissions in Computer Science majors.

Department of Labor statistics show that job creation in software occupations
have stagnated. Despite this, the vast majority of H-1b and L1 visas are
intended for that occupation. The greatest users of this visa are in fact
Indian outsourcing firms such as Infosys, Wipro, and Tata. In these cases the
visa is used to streamline the offshoring of high-skilled jobs.

I propose that the DOL and USCIS use labor statistics to better determine what
occupations are eligible for the H-1b and L1 visa programs. A detailed document
is attached for review. There is no reason that additional H-1b visas are
granted to software professionals.
